page.title: 15PARISH OF TIBBERMORE (8)
page.content: There was also a church and a joiners workshop, also a blacksmith. Now all these have been closed and the local children now go by bus to school in Methven. For entertainment, the local community would assemble in the school, the centre of all leisure activity, where, on a Friday night,they would enjoy a whist drive, followed by a dance. A large number of people were engaged on the land and they were employed by the farmer on a six monthly contract. These contracts were made at the Whitsun Term or the Martinmas Term. The result of this type of employment was that the school population virtually changed completely twice a year. With the coming of mechanisation this pattern changed. The agricultural workers lived in small tied cottages and would 'flit' from farm to farm.
